title: R43808
content: The Army is composed of an Active Component (AC) and a Reserve Component (RC), with debates over the distribution of units between them. Advocates either favor a stronger AC emphasis or a stronger RC emphasis, with some believing RC units can replace AC force structure while saving money. The distribution of units between the Active Component (AC) and Reserve Component (RC) in the Army is a topic of debate. Advocates of a stronger AC emphasis argue that replacing certain AC units with RC units may not be cost-effective and could hinder the Army's ability to respond rapidly to crises. Congress plays a significant role in determining the AC/RC force mix, with broad powers over the armed forces outlined in the Constitution. Congress plays a significant role in authorizing and funding the Army's Active Component (AC) and Reserve Component (RC), setting end strengths, ensuring proper equipment and supplies, determining pay and benefits, establishing personnel policies, and overseeing the Department of Defense. It also has the authority to allocate roles and missions, adjust reserve activation authorities, determine training regimens, establish or disestablish units, specify unit composition, and designate the number and types of units within each component. In recent years, interest in the AC/RC mix has grown, especially for the Army, due to large-scale mobilizations of RC forces in Iraq and Afghanistan. Concerns about federal spending and budget constraints have led to considerations of shifting towards a more cost-effective RC force structure. The Administration's FY2015 budget request proposes this shift towards the RC. The Administration proposes shifting the AC/RC mix towards the RC, with RC forces making up 54.1% of the Army by FY2017. There are discussions about reallocating brigade combat teams towards the ARNG, and the Army's Aviation Restructuring Initiative suggests moving attack helicopters to the AC. Other proposals recommend a greater shift towards the RC, with RC forces making up 58% of the Army. The debate over the Army's force structure mix between active and reserve components intensifies in Congress, with discussions on the importance and relevance of each component in the future strategic environment. Competition for resources between the active and reserve components will be a key issue in the 113th Congress. Competition between active and reserve components for resources will fuel debate, as seen in the Air Force's force structure recommendations. The ratio of AC and RC forces has shifted over time, with Congress playing a central role. Historically, force structure was mainly in the reserve component, except during major conflicts when the active component was expanded. During World War II, the U.S. armed forces grew from 350,000 to over 12 million personnel. After the war, the size was reduced to 1.5 million, but during the Korean War in 1950, it doubled to 3.2 million with a major reserve mobilization. The active force size remained relatively stable in the following decade. Since the Korean War, the United States has maintained most of its force structure in the active component, with a slight majority of Army force structure being in the reserve component since 1989. Active duty forces continue to dominate the military, unlike the pre-World War II era when militia and reserve forces outnumbered standing elements. The American military posture is still dominated by standing forces of the four military services, despite a shift towards ready reserves since the Cold War. The Total Force Policy, established in 1973, aimed to integrate Active, Guard, and Reserve forces into a cohesive unit. General Creighton Abrams implemented a policy to integrate Guard and Reserve forces with the active Army, rebuilding it to 16 divisions within budgetary limits. This ensured that the Army could not be deployed to war without the Guard and Reserve, as seen in Vietnam. The roundout brigade program was a key aspect of this integration, restructuring certain divisions to include Reserve Component brigades. In the 1970s and 1980s, initiatives were implemented to improve active-reserve integration, including assigning AC divisions two AC brigades and a "roundout" National Guard brigade. A new law in 1976 made it easier to activate RC personnel. The Persian Gulf War in 1990-91 tested this integration, with over 238,000 RC personnel activated, strengthening support for the Total Force Policy. RC performance in the conflict supported the Total Force Policy, but areas of readiness needed improvement, particularly with the roundout brigades. Three ARNG brigades were mobilized for Operation Desert Shield, but faced delays and readiness deficiencies, not becoming combat ready until after the war ended. The roundout brigades were not activated until four months after Desert Shield began, did not deploy with their parent divisions, and were not combat ready until the day of the cease-fire. Controversy arose over their viability and readiness levels, with criticism focused on their lack of readiness to deploy immediately in response to a crisis. The roundout brigades faced readiness problems before Desert Shield/Storm but were validated for deployment three months after activation. The Persian Gulf War led to reforms with the Army National Guard Combat Readiness Reform Act of 1992, focusing on improving ARNG combat units' readiness and compatibility with AC units. The Army National Guard Combat Readiness Reform Act of 1992 aimed to enhance ARNG readiness by recruiting experienced personnel, revising training focus, improving medical evaluations, ensuring system compatibility, and providing more funding for early deploying units. The end of the roundout brigade program in 1993, coupled with the Soviet Union's collapse, accelerated the integration of Active Component (AC) and Reserve Component (RC) forces. During the post-Cold War era, the Army National Guard and Army Reserve underwent restructuring to align with reduced force requirements. The Army National Guard retained combat and support units, while the Army Reserve focused on support roles and provided Echelon Above Division and Echelon Above Corps units. The drawdown was followed by increased deployment of Reserve Component forces in various conflicts. The increased deployment of Reserve Component forces in conflicts like Iraq, Bosnia, Kosovo, and Haiti led to a shift in perspective on their suitability as substitutes for Active Component units. The performance of RC units in Iraq and Afghanistan validated the Total Force Policy, although some argue that AC and RC units are not interchangeable. The deployment of Reserve Component forces in Iraq and Afghanistan led to debates over their effectiveness compared to Active Component units. Despite arguments that RC units had less complex missions, advocates claim they were effective and could have handled combined arms maneuver missions if given the opportunity. Congress authorized expansions of the active Army and Marine Corps during these conflicts, leading to a higher ratio of AC to RC forces. However, with the end of the wars and ongoing reduction of forces, a multi-year drawdown of AC forces is underway, likely resulting in a decline in the proportion of AC to RC forces in these Services. The Army consists of an Active Component and two Reserve Components: the Army National Guard and the Army Reserve. The Active Component includes soldiers who serve full-time and can be deployed worldwide for various military operations. It comprises both combat and support units. The Army's reserve components, the Army National Guard of the United States and the United States Army Reserve, provide trained units and qualified personnel for active duty in times of war or national emergency. The Army National Guard also has a state role, stemming from colonial-era militias. The USAR, established in 1908, is a purely federal entity with direct combat and support units. The US Army Reserve (USAR) is a federal entity composed mainly of support units. Part-time soldiers train regularly, with full-time support personnel making up 14% of total strength. Unlike the Army National Guard, the USAR is always under federal control and focuses on brigade-level operations. Brigades can operate independently and can be combined with other units for missions. The US Army Reserve is composed mainly of support units and focuses on brigade-level operations. Brigades can be combined with other units to form divisions, corps, and armies for large-scale operations.
